Title.evidence: Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Acupuncture for Acute Pain in the Emergency Department

Trial_Design.evidence: This NIH-funded multi-site feasibility study employed a randomised controlled trial design.

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they presented with acute pain in the ED, including trauma, low back pain, abdominal pain, musculoskeletal pain, renal colic, or headache.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a flexible acupuncture treatment tailored to common ED scenarios, while the control group received usual care.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the feasibility of acupuncture as a safer alternative for acute pain management in the ED.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain reduction, measured immediately post-intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible for patients and clinicians, but outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group, recruited between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Data from 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a significant reduction in pain compared to the control group (mean difference = 5.2 mm Hg, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, occurring in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.

Funding.evidence: This study was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
